{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3159889,"name":"Jason Johnson","username":"jsjohn2000","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/a88e57/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-03-08T04:55:09.079Z","cooked":"

Our team is using a PID controller to control the arm we will be using to get game elements. We need to resolve how to get the code working and our first competition this Saturday.

frc6239/compbot-2023: Repository for the competition bot for the 2023 FRC season. (github.com)

Suggestions and advice to get working code or an alternative to get something working is greatly appreciated. Details below…

We started with the ArmBot from the First WPILIB examples. We do not have an encoder to install on the arm mechanism. We are using the built in Relative Encoder on the Neo via the SparkMax motor controller.

The team is running into difficulty setting up the constants and the PositionConversionFactor to get the code working. It is our understanding that the ArmFeedforward and Plant for PID needs to be in units of radians. We are using radians to establish the set points for our arm. The initial position is vertical perpendicular to the ground (-90 degrees offset from horizontal).

NEO Relative Encoder returns a value from 0-1 when you call getPosition. In the constructor setPositionConversionFactor is called with 1/(2PI). When the motor turns one revolution the position is 1/(2PI). It is our understanding this should be 2*PI when the getPosition reads 1.0.

For testing we have used the following constants and have not connected the arm.

public static final double kVVoltSecondPerRad = 0.5; // was 0.5
public static final double kAVoltSecondSquaredPerRad = 0.1; // was 0.1

When we have any position conversion factor > 1.0 the motor will start spinning uncontrollably back and forth and we have to disable the robot.

I believe found one of the issues. When the position conversion factor is 2*pi a rotation will be that number of radians. The PID is asked to goto Math.toRadians(45.0) * GEARBOX_RATIO

In useOutput the voltage of the battery is set to the process variable (where we want motor to go) plus arm feed forward. The value of output increases well above 12Volts

Should we be setting position conversion factor to 2*pi /Gearbox ratio?

jsjohn2000:

Should we be setting position conversion factor to 2*pi /Gearbox ratio?

That would be the best practice, yes. You could find good feedforward constants either way, but they will be more interpretable this way. And closer to correct if you ever change the gear ratio. Most importantly, you can confirm the encoder is reading approximately correctly by looking at the arm position and comparing against the encoder position.

Thank you for that confirmation. We are going to make the change tonight and test. We are going to tell the motor controller to set the Pcf to 1.0 and handle it in our code. We will do that by scaling getPosition in the getMeasurement method. Hopefully it works as we are down to the wire before our first competition.

We have a 100:1 gearbox connected to the motor. I anticipate there is another scale factor we might need to consider. We will probably go from -90 to 0 and look at the encoder position. We will then calculate the scale factor to account and multiple 2*pi/gearboxratio by that.
